Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: They notice swimmers occasionally entering the shallow area without supervision.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, laughing with my family as we tossed around ideas for the weekend. My little brother wanted to go to the community pool, and everyone seemed excited. As the oldest, I was expected to join in, help wrangle the younger kids, and make the day special. But as a lifeguard, I knew the pool had strict rules—no one was supposed to be in the shallow end without a lifeguard present. Last weekend, I’d seen a few swimmers slip into that area when no one was watching, and it gnawed at me. My parents looked at me, waiting for my input, expecting me to be part of the fun. At the same time, I felt the weight of my responsibility to enforce the rules and keep everyone safe. My mind raced, torn between being the supportive sibling my family wanted and the vigilant lifeguard I was trained to be. I could feel the tension building inside me as I tried to figure out what to say.
